Purpose
The purpose of this Document is to define the Standard Operational Policy for the newly developed Surgical Assessment Unit (SAU) within the Surgical Emergency ward (SEW) from March 2017.
Introduction
The Surgical Assessment ward sits within the Surgical Emergency Ward (SEW) within the Surgical Directorate
The Surgical Assessment Unit (SAU) is located within the Surgical Emergency ward (SEW) on level 2 of the South Block Building. Its entrance is at B344.
SAU/SEW comprises of:
Patient reception for administration staff and a waiting area for up to 8 surgical emergency patients referred by the Emergency dept. (ED); GP or OPD referrals;
Clinical assessment/Minor Ops room;
Sisters Office with telephone and PC access including conference facility for clinical handover meetings;
Assessment /Triage room with telephone and PC access;
Male/female toilet facilities;
Dirty Utility room;
Linen room, staff toilet;
Staff locker room;
Stationary store room;
Clinical room for drug preparation;
Nurse Stations x2 with telephone and PC access;
Bay 1 with 9 beds and 1 isolation room with en-suite facility (Female single sex accommodation);
Patient shower room and toilet facility for both bays;
Bay 2 with 8 beds and 1 isolation room with en-suite facility (Male single sex accommodation);
Kitchen facilities.
Scope
The SAU – will be run by the SEW nursing staff and SpR 8-6 Monday to Friday. The SEW will be open 24/7, 365 days per year.

The principal benefit of the service to the patient is that, they will be able to access a surgical assessment area providing emergency assessment, triage, investigation, treatment and discharge in a single hospital area, carried out by a specialist medical, nursing and AHP multidisciplinary team.
Patients may be referred by GPs, A&E staff and other surgical staff from within MEHT e.g. OPD referrals via the following bleep numbers and unit extensions:
SAU/SEW reception: Extension: 6390 SPR Bleep: #6555 1440
NIC Bleep: #6555 1160.

Referrals from ED, GP's or OPD will be made by telephone, fax or email to the duty surgical registrar that is based on SAU from 8am-6pm only. After 6pm all surgical emergency referrals will be made to the on-call team via the emergency bleep system. All referrals will be documented on the approved referral form in appendix 1, for auditing purposes.
If the duty SpR is unavailable the on-call Consultant will always be available, at least by telephone, to advise about the acceptability of a referral.

All ED referrals with be triaged within 30 minutes of referral either in the ED department, or accepted by the SPR and transferred to wait in the waiting area of SAU; this area can hold a maximum of 8 patient referrals, after this time, the SPR will assess in ED, whilst the on-call team assess on SAU to deal with any large influx of patient issues.
All patients will be seen and treated in accordance with the same targets as apply to A&E or EAU attenders i.e. within 4 hours of attending
Intra-hospital referrals (A&E or OPD) will be transferred immediately where possible.

On acceptance of a GP referral, a suitable time will be agreed for the patient to attend. If clinically urgent there will be no delay, but if not clinically mandated and if the unit is busy, a later time may be agreed.
Patients will be registered at the front desk by the ward clerk.
Out of hours - Patients will be registered by a member of the nursing team.
After acceptance the patient's details will be logged into Lorenzo in the usual manner.
Where possible the old notes will be retrieved prior to arrival of the patient.
GP referrals to the surgical service will not need to attend the A&E or EAU departments, freeing capacity there for other users. There are 2 exception to
this rule:
After initial assessment and investigation a number of routes will be available to the patient:
Patients may be discharged home and/or back to their GP.

Patients may be discharged home with a follow up appointment to either re- attend SAU or Radiology on an alternative date, and review of any scans/investigations performed will dictate further treatment via SAU, OPD or GP.
Medically unstable patients will be transferred without delay to the most appropriate facility which could be Critical Care, Theatres, Heybridge or Rayne wards.
Patients deemed urgent for admission beds will be accommodated across the surgical floor dependent on their expected length of stay (LOS) within the Trust i.e. LOS < 72 hours on SEW.

SAU will consider the following conditions for acceptance: minor head injury, abscess, rectal bleed, non-specific abdominal pain (although many of these may be discharged for Urgent Review Clinic (URC) follow-up), cholecystitis, biliary colic requiring analgesia, mild pancreatitis, urinary retention, ureteric colic, bowel obstruction, stoma issues - this is not an exclusive list.

There will be a full consultant led ward round every morning after the 0830 handover, and a “sweep” review round in the evening after theatre. Urology patients will similarly be seen by an appropriate grade specialist.
Radiology will provide 6-8 slots per day for emergency scans/investigations to provide a quick and efficient emergency service.

Patients not needing hospital admission may be discharged home to return for review in the Urgent Review Clinic (URC) by the on call Consultant or SPR the following day. An imaging service will be available for such patients from 9am, to be followed by the URC at ~10am daily.
Patients may be directed to Out Patient investigation and follow-up with the SAU/SEW system at any stage in the patient pathway, then discharged back to
primary care, whether they have been admitted or not, a suitable communication to the GP will be provided at the time of discharge. A non-negotiable 100% target will be imposed on this standard.
Patients will not be seen in the SAU if they are under 16 years of age. The SAU is not a replacement for ED and self-referrals will not be accepted.
They will only be seen if appropriately referred by a doctor.
Inclusion Criteria
GP referral to Consultant /Registrar/Senior Surgical Sister;
ED referral to Consultant /Registrar/Senior Surgical Sister;
Out-patient clinic referral to Consultant /Registrar/Senior Surgical Sister;
Repatriation/specialist referral from neighbouring hospital to Consultant /Registrar/Senior Surgical Sister;
Referral of surgical patient on non-surgical ward.
Exclusion Criteria
Children Under the age of 16 years;
Acute Surgical patients whose condition on arrival may require resuscitation;
Acute surgical patient arriving without prior clinician involvement;
Patients arriving to the SAU with a GP letter but without prior GP; consultation with the SAU SPR, Nurse in charge of SEW or the Surgical on- call team;
Patients not requiring surgical review or intervention.
4.1.2  The above groups of patients in 4.1 should be referred directly to the Emergency Department.
Estimated Total Service Activity & Patient Flow
This is a new ward and all Service activity is based on General surgical outlier
capacity in other specialities. (Refer to Patient Flow is shown in the appendices).
Supply Flow
Top up system provided by procurement management
Weekly restocking of shelves from stock items
Non stock items- ordering of non-stock items on an as and when needed basis from relevant suppliers via procurement and goods receiving
Staffing
Specialist Surgical Staff
Nursing Staff
Skill mix based upon MEHT/NMC Guidelines and in accordance with NMC Guidelines on staffing for emergency Departments;
SAU/SEW Senior Sister/Charge Nurse is responsible for overall efficiency of the integrated unit supported by the Junior sister/charge nurses;
Access to Specialist Nurses via telephone and e-mail to arrange a ward visit/assessment;
Staff will rotate through all areas of the unit and should be competent to work in all clinical areas where required;
At a junior level staff will be trained to work in any area of the unit covering all basic procedures as appropriate;
More experienced staff may be encouraged to develop sub-specialist skills in particular advanced procedures;
A multi-disciplinary team approach – ensuring effective communication;
All staff will adhere to NMC Guidelines & Trust unit policies.
Therapies – awaiting allocation of these staff.
Dietetics – awaiting allocation of these staff.
Training and Education
All Staff Training will be delivered in line with the Mandatory Training Policy and training needs analysis.
All staff training to be competency based.
In addition education for nursing and support staff within SEW is the responsibility of each staff member, utilising both in-house and external resources.
It is the responsibility of the management team to encourage and support “life long learning” as identified in each staffs' appraisal.
The hospital has a library facility for the use of all staff.
The Training and Development Department is accessible via the hospital intranet service, and has e-learning facilities.
Staff Facilities
All facilities that are now shared within the SAU/SEW/Level 2 Radiology department are:
Staff changing rooms;
Male/female with toileting facilities;
Lockers;
Kitchen facilities;
Ward clerk responsibilities.
Responsibilities
All Consultants are responsible and accountable for the service provided to patients as per Consultant contract.
All staff are accountable and responsible for patient care within SAU/SEW as per their Trust contract

The Chief Operating Officer and Assistant Chief Operating Officer for Surgery in conjunction with the Clinical Director, Assistant Chief Nurse and Matrons for Surgery are operationally responsible for all decisions and/or changes made to SAU/SEW.
Finance leads for SAU/SEW sit within the Surgical Directorate, and liaise with the Clinical Director (CD) for Surgery, Matron for Surgery and the Senior Sister for SAU/SEW.
All patients attending the ward must have an accurate record of medical, nursing and multi-professional care whilst on the ward.

Key Requirements for Facilities Management (F.M.)
11.3.1 Fire
Fire risk assessments, review by the Fire officer and method of access in fire drill/alarm;
The service will be compliant with the Trust's Fire Safety Policy, Fire Evacuation Policy and other local fire plans and procedures.”
(The detail of these items will then be developed as part of the separate Fire Safety Work Programme, as led by the Trust's Fire Officer).
11.3.2 Laundry services
Clean linen will be supplied daily to the department as an arranged topping up system, by the contracted company, and stored in an allocated storeroom.
Dirty Linen will be collected by staff and placed in bags within the dedicated linen disposal room (in line with Trust Waste Policy).
11.3.3Sluice Facilities
Sluice facilities will be used in accordance with infection prevention policy.
11.3.3 Catering
There are catering facilities in the department.
11.3.4 Pharmacy
Pharmacy supplies will be supplied on a “topping up” basis other than for scheduled and dangerous drugs which will be supplied on a direct requisition basis.
11.3.5 Disposal
All items for disposal will be taken to a designated Disposal Room in accordance with Trust Waste Policy.
11.3.6 Housekeeping
Cleaning will be provided Monday to Sunday between 0700 and 2100 and will be checked in accordance with trust policy.
11.3.7 Portering
The portering department will undertake patient movement duties, collection and delivery services and any other ad hoc duties as requested.
11.3.8 Maintenance
Estates staff will undertake routine maintenance services, certain items of planned preventative maintenance on a cyclical basis and other ad hoc maintenance initiated on a requisition basis.
11.3.9 Materials management
A topping up service for all Supplies will be available to agreed levels
BME will provide a service for certain items as agreed, within the service Level agreement (SLA). Other items will be maintained by warranty/maintenance agreements
Environmental Requirements
Decoration and colour scheme for clinical areas should be in line with Trust corporate approach but must be open and friendly for users.
Access to private areas/rooms to conduct sensitive conversations in close proximity to where the patient is being seen, adhering to the Trust Privacy and Dignity Policy..
All changing areas adhere to the Trust same sex policy to ensure patients' privacy and dignity are protected at all times.
Patient Way finding
There is a designated reception area.
Emergency Requirements
All SAU/SEW rooms, must have an emergency call bell.
The Resuscitation Trolley must be checked as per Trust policy and ready for use at any time.
In the event of a cardiac arrest staff must call 2222, for a fire 2999 and for security
ICT Requirements
The SAU/SEW department and administration team will require access to computers, printers and the following hospital based facilities:
PAS;
Symphony;
Extramed with GP direct facility;
Infloflex;
PACS;
MEHT Review;
Tomcat;
Theatreman;
Email;
Internet;
Conference room style big screen for handover meetings in office.
N.B Other systems may be needed and these above are for illustrative purposes.
The ability to produce information (electronic or printed) for patients on their condition and the further treatment they will receive.
Telephones.
Faxing/scanning and printing capacity
16.0. Equipment Requirements
The following equipment is required in the SAU/SEW:
Beds x19;
Side rooms x2;
Resuscitation trolley;
(Diathermy);
Monitoring equipment per bay and procedure rooms;
ICT equipment as stated in 8.1;
(Couches (x1) for each assessment room);
Curtained changing areas for patients;
Changing rooms for staff;
Sisters Office for Doctors handover;
Sluice with Bedpan washer and Commode (x1);
Storage rooms for consumables;
Linen trolley;
Disposal rooms for waste.
Information Security
Patient identifiable data or sensitive data must never be emailed out of the trust unless the information is encrypted or sent from and to an nhs.net account.
Patient information must never be downloaded onto any unencrypted mobile device.
All routine sharing of patient information must be agreed with a signed Data Sharing Agreement.
All staff must adhere to the Trust Information Governance and IT Security policies listed in the Information Governance Handbook.
Medical Records
Patients Medical notes must be stored in a designated safe secure area within the SAU/SEW.
Patient information must be secure at all times within the department.
All staff must adhere to the Trust Health Records Policy and Casenote Tracking Policy.
Consent
All patients consent to treatment in line with the Trust Consent Policy
It is the responsibility of staff providing treatment or care to a patient with capacity to ensure that valid consent has been obtained from the patient before providing that treatment or care.
Records of competency to take delegated consent for doctors in training will be maintained by Medical Resources.

Staff have a legal duty to have regard to the provisions of the Mental Capacity Act 2005 and the Code of Practice when they have to take decisions on behalf of a person who lacks the mental capacity to take that decision for himself
Patients have the right to withdraw their consent at any stage during their treatment a per guidelines
20.0. Contingency

In the event that SAU/SEW is full of patients and cannot transfer patients to Heybridge or Rayne wards, or discharge patients to create capacity, the Nurse in charge of SAU/SEW will contact ED and the clinical operations team to inform them of the need to take all surgical admissions via the A&E route until this situation can be rectified. This will be escalated to the Clinical Director and Associate chief Nurse for Surgery.
In the event of an incident the service would refer to the Trust incident Policy and the Trust Business Continuity Policy.
In the event of the computer system not being available for results the relevant department would be contacted by phone.
In the event of the Trust telephone system being unavailable, Trust policy regarding internal incident or business continuity would be followed.

In the event of a shortage of specialist staff able to carry out the relevant procedures, temporary staff allocated by the Staff bank or another outside agency will be requested to backfill these shortages.
In the event of IT failure, paper documentation is completed and uploaded when IT systems are re-established.
Auditing this Policy

This is a new facility and the operational systems will inevitably evolve and improve with time. Careful audit of the patient flows with daily numbers will be essential to direct this evolution and to monitor the success of the facility.
Audit data will be scrutinised monthly by the whole emergency MDT.

Breaches of this policy will be reported via the Datix web system, where trends can be identified and brought to the attention of the management and clinical stakeholders. This will include failure/breakdown of equipment impairing service delivery, management of staff sickness and resultant treatment capacity deficits.
Patient Safety and Quality Committee will be supplied with Datix trend data, and incidents requiring immediate assessment will be fed back directly.

Surgical Sisters meetings held monthly and Surgical Governance meetings, held bi-monthly. The aim of these meetings is to share best practice, shape service development and actively monitor risks and performance and feed directly in to the Service.
Auditing of the SEW via CQC and MEHT Infection prevention policies, ensures that this department reaches the necessary requirements for the relevant accreditation and standards of Practice.
